all_data.transcript: Yeah, so certainly humans are pretty decoupled from the circadian environment in the modern world. Um, so we're we're really interested in considering time as a variable and in a circadian system, the clock in your brain synchronizes to the external environment, but you also have molecular clocks in every other tissue, um, including in your gut and in your liver, um, and in other metabolic tissues. all_data.speaker: Annika Barber
all_data.transcript: And what this can lead to is circadian desynchrony where basically different tissues tell different times. So all of the organ systems are temporarily coordinated with each other. But if you do things like eat in the middle of the night, drink caffeine, use drugs of abuse, use pharmaceutical drugs, um, you know, eliminate your microbiome, take antibiotics, um, you can provide these new entrainment cues for your gut.

all_data.transcript: Um, so we're that's something that I'm really intrigued by. So I in my postdoc lab I focused on circadian rhythms of locomotor behavior. They all have a peak of activity in the morning and a peak of activity in the evening. Um, and I got really interested in investigating feeding rhythms, which is something newer in flies because we haven't really had the resolution to look at single fly feeding until more recently. Um, and so when I started to look at feeding, I thought that their feeding patterns would follow their locomotor activity, that they would eat the most when they were walking up, walking around, being awake the most. Um, and I thought that when I looked at classic circadian locomotor rhythm mutants that I would see the same deficits in their feeding rhythms. And what I found is that for flies, um locomotor activity and feeding rhythms are very decoupled.
